questions.prompt: In the purport to BG 2.1, what does Srila Prabhupada say about Arjuna's compassion?
choices: Material compassion for the dress of a drowning man is senseless
Compassion means refusing to fight to avoid causing bodily harm
Any kind of compassion reflects true spiritual advancement regardless of object
Expressing compassion for family members shows proper understanding of relationships
questions.feedback: Correct: Srila Prabhupada explains that compassion for the eternal soul is self-realization, while compassion for the gross material body is senseless-like saving a drowning man by rescuing only his clothes. Arjuna's compassion targets the wrong object (relatives' bodies), producing confusion rather than clarity. Why this matters: Material sentimentality masquerades as transcendental mercy when we focus on the body's temporary distress while neglecting the soul's eternal welfare.

questions.prompt: In BG 2.2, what does Krishna say about Arjuna's impurities (kasmalam)?
choices: They are befitting a warrior overwhelmed by family love
They lead not to higher planets but to infamy
They demonstrate proper respect for elders and superiors
They show Arjuna's advanced understanding of compassionate principles
questions.feedback: Correct: Krishna calls Arjuna's weakness kasmalam, not befitting an Aryan, and warns it leads to infamy, not higher elevation. He treats it as contamination that covers duty, not as a virtue. This shows that sentimental softness can be a disguise for bodily illusion.

questions.prompt: Why does Arjuna's respect for Bhisma and Drona create a moral dilemma in BG 2.4?
choices: They represent both his enemies and those worthy of worship
They are worthy of worship, so fighting them is never permissible
They are weaker than him but demand false respect
They have betrayed their duty as warriors in this conflict
questions.feedback: Correct: Bhisma and Drona oppose Arjuna yet remain worshipable, creating a duty dilemma. Respect does not automatically cancel prescribed duty when elders support adharma. Arjuna must learn to honor persons while not endorsing their present side.

questions.prompt: What attitude does Arjuna adopt in BG 2.7 toward Krsna?
choices: He asks Krsna for advice but keeps final decision
He surrenders as a disciple and asks for instruction
He seeks reassurance from Krsna without accepting discipline
He treats Krsna as equal friend not spiritual master
questions.feedback: Correct: Arjuna surrenders as a disciple and asks Krishna to instruct him. This is a shift from taking advice to accepting authority. Without surrender, Krishna's teaching would remain optional rather than decisive.

questions.prompt: In the purport to BG 2.11, what false path does Srila Prabhupada warn against regarding lamentation?
choices: That emotional expression for material loss demonstrates spiritual sensitivity and advancement
That the wise lament neither the living nor dead recognizing soul eternality
That grieving for the soul's temporary bondage shows proper spiritual understanding
That expressing compassion through lamentation indicates evolved consciousness and empathy
questions.feedback: Correct: Srila Prabhupada explains that lamentation for material bodies-living or dead-indicates ignorance of the soul's eternal nature (pandita sama-darshina). The wise neither lament the living nor the dead because they recognize the soul beyond bodily modifications. Material sentiment (attachment to bodies) differs categorically from spiritual wisdom (vision of soul).

questions.prompt: In BG 2.12, what does Krishna establish about individual existence?
choices: There was a time when we did not exist
Never was there a time when I did not exist
Individuality is temporary illusion that will end after liberation
All beings merge into one existence in the future
questions.feedback: Correct: Krishna declares 'na tv evaham jatu nasam'-never was there a time when I did not exist, nor you, nor these kings; nor shall any cease to be. Why this matters: The verse explicitly establishes eternal individuality (aham, tvam, ime) refuting both Buddhist momentariness and Mayavada merging. Personal eternal relationship with Krishna is sanatana-dharma's foundation-not achieving undifferentiated oneness but perfecting loving service to the eternally distinct Lord.

questions.prompt: How does BG 2.13 illustrate the soul's continuity through bodily changes?
choices: Like a river flowing continuously through different changing landscapes
As embodied soul passes from boyhood to youth to age
Like seasons changing from spring to summer to winter
As consciousness expands from childhood ignorance to mature wisdom
questions.feedback: Correct: The same dehi passes from boyhood to youth to old age while the body changes. This everyday continuity supports the next step: death is another change of body, not the end of the self. Therefore grief based on bodily change is misplaced.

questions.prompt: Why does BG 2.14 compare happiness and distress to summer and winter?
choices: To show they are unavoidable and must be accepted as destiny
Temporary sensations come and go like seasons; endure them
Happiness and distress alternate predictably like seasonal weather cycles
To demonstrate that both states are equally valuable for spiritual growth
questions.feedback: Correct: Happiness and distress arise from sense contact and come and go like seasons. Knowing they are temporary supports tolerance rather than panic or craving. Equanimity flows from clear perception, not forced numbness.

questions.prompt: According to BG 2.15, who is eligible for liberation?
choices: One disturbed by happiness and distress in daily life's situations
One steady and not disturbed by happiness or distress
One who accumulates wealth through honest work and material endeavors
One who renounces without understanding the goal of life
questions.feedback: Correct: The dhira who is not disturbed by happiness and distress becomes fit for liberation. Qualification is about steadiness of consciousness, not perfect external conditions. Spiritual life is practiced now, amid dualities.

questions.prompt: In BG 2.31, what does Krishna say a kshatriya should consider regarding a righteous fight?
choices: It is better to avoid all warfare for spiritual advancement
Nothing is higher for a kshatriya than a righteous fight
Fighting relatives is always spiritually contaminating
One should postpone battle until achieving complete detachment
questions.feedback: Correct: Krishna declares that for a kshatriya, nothing is higher than dharmyad yuddhad (righteous war)-this isn't concession but affirmation of varna-dharma's validity. Fighting in accordance with prescribed duty isn't spiritually neutral but positively righteous when performed without material attachment. This establishes that renouncing one's dharma isn't spiritual advancement but dereliction disguised as transcendence.

questions.prompt: In the purport to BG 2.20, what does Srila Prabhupada explain as the symptom of the soul's presence?
choices: The warmth and life energy circulating through the body
Consciousness spread throughout the body like sunlight from the sun
The breath moving in and out indicating vitality
The ability to think and reason distinguishing humans from animals
questions.feedback: Correct: Consciousness is the symptom of the soul, like sunshine indicates the sun. It is not a product of matter but evidence of the living self within the body. When consciousness is absent, the soul has departed.

questions.prompt: How does the garment analogy in BG 2.22 refute the fear of death?
choices: Death brings complete annihilation of existence and identity
It shows the soul remains unchanged while bodies are exchanged
Individual identity ceases when the soul merges into the supreme
Consciousness ceases when the body dies since both are interdependent
questions.feedback: Correct: As a person discards old clothes and accepts new ones, the soul changes bodies. The self remains the same while the outer covering is replaced. This reframes death as transition, not annihilation.

questions.prompt: Why does BG 2.25 emphasize the soul as invisible, inconceivable and immutable?
choices: Only what can be measured and perceived exists in reality
To show the soul transcends material perception and speculation
The soul is merely a temporary combination of material elements
What cannot be seen or touched must not truly exist
questions.feedback: Correct: The soul is described as invisible, inconceivable, and immutable, beyond material measurement. Because it does not change, bodily events cannot touch it. Realization requires hearing from shabda-pramana, not only sense-based proof.

questions.prompt: In BG 2.30, why need one not grieve for any living being?
choices: Because grieving shows devotion and humility toward those who leave
Because he who dwells in the body can not be slain
Because the soul will be reborn anyway, so grief is unnecessary
Because suffering is only imagination, so grief is pointless
questions.feedback: Correct: The indwelling self cannot be slain, so lamentation has no ultimate basis. The body can be destroyed, but the soul is unaffected. This ends grief at the root, not merely by offering consolation.

questions.prompt: According to BG 2.47, what is the proper relationship between work and its results?
choices: One has right to fruits if work is done properly
One has right to perform duty but not to fruits
One should avoid work entirely to prevent attachment to results
One should work only when results are guaranteed to be favorable
questions.feedback: Correct: The verse establishes adhikara (right) to karmani (prescribed work) but not to phaleshu (fruits)-a revolutionary principle separating action from result. Why this matters: Results-driven action means performing duty contingent on guaranteed outcomes, producing anxiety and attachment. Right to action exists unconditionally; right to results doesn't exist at all-results belong to Krishna's arrangement. Perform duty as offering regardless of result, transforming work from selfish transaction to selfless service.

questions.prompt: In BG 2.49, how does Krishna characterize work done for fruitive results compared to buddhi-yoga?
choices: Fruitive work can be offered to Krishna later for purification
Abominable activities should be kept far distant by devotional service
Planning one's work intelligently demonstrates buddhi-yoga in practice
Desiring fruits from work is natural and spiritually neutral
questions.feedback: Correct: Krishna calls fruitive work inferior and tells Arjuna to keep it far away by buddhi-yoga. Desire for results binds one to anxiety and exploitation mentality. Buddhi-yoga is a different aim: duty as offering, not transaction.

questions.prompt: According to BG 2.55, what characterizes one in pure transcendental consciousness (sthita-prajna)?
choices: One who moderates all sense desires through strict disciplined regulation
One who gives up all sense desires, satisfied in the self alone
One who fulfills all desires systematically to achieve final detachment
One who analyzes desires philosophically before acting on them selectively
questions.feedback: Correct: The sthita-prajna gives up sense-gratificatory desires and is satisfied in the self. This is not suppression but a higher satisfaction replacing lower cravings. Krishna consciousness reduces desire by higher taste.

questions.prompt: How do the arguments about the soul's eternality (BG 2.12-25) and Arjuna's warrior duty (BG 2.31-32) work together to resolve his crisis?
choices: Both reveal duty transcends personal comfort; act despite difficulty
Eternal soul makes death illusory; kshatriya duty makes fighting righteous
They contradict each other revealing inconsistency in teaching
Either fighting or fleeing would be acceptable since all choices are relative
questions.feedback: Correct: Krishna synthesizes metaphysics (2.12-25 soul eternality) with ethics (2.31-32 kshatriya duty)-a two-pronged resolution. The soul's indestructibility removes philosophical objection (can't truly kill anyone); kshatriya-dharma provides positive justification (righteous war for righteous warrior). Together they eliminate paralysis: metaphysical security plus ethical imperative produce fearless righteous action.

questions.prompt: How does Prabhupada's teaching on tolerating dualities (BG 2.14-15) inform the instruction to perform duty with equanimity (BG 2.48)?
choices: Forcefully suppressing all emotional reactions creates true spiritual detachment
Recognizing impermanence of sense experience enables balanced action in duties
Work outcomes are predetermined by fate so they don't actually matter
Experiencing material pleasures helps one advance spiritually through gradual satisfaction
questions.feedback: Correct: Seeing dualities as temporary (2.14-15) supports yoga-stha action (2.48). Insight into impermanence makes outcomes less gripping, enabling steady duty. Equanimity is born from knowledge, not forced stoicism.

questions.prompt: In the purport to BG 2.7, what false path does Srila Prabhupada warn against regarding family attachment?
choices: Families naturally protect each other from death eternally
Family attachment is based on 'skin disease' mentality
Only humans can be affectionate to relatives and family
Society can definitely save one from death through collective effort
questions.feedback: Correct: Prabhupada calls family attachment a 'skin disease' when it is treated as ultimate shelter. Why this matters: Family duty remains, but family cannot save one from death or give final security. Use family life as a field of service, not as the soul's refuge.

questions.prompt: In the purport to BG 2.7, who does Srila Prabhupada describe as a miserly person (krpana)?
choices: One who hoards wealth through legitimate means and proper work
One who solves life's problems as a human should
One who quits without understanding self-realization like cats and dogs
One who becomes detached from family life and material affairs
questions.feedback: Correct: The krpana (miser) quits life without solving the human form's purpose-like cats and dogs dying without self-realization. Human life's value lies in potential for self-realization; squandering this through material pursuit alone constitutes ultimate miserliness. Cats and dogs cannot inquire about transcendence; humans who don't are voluntarily reducing themselves to animal consciousness.

questions.prompt: In BG 2.33, what consequence does Krishna warn if Arjuna refuses to fight?
choices: He will achieve renunciation through peaceful non-violence
He will incur sin and lose his reputation as a warrior
He will be honored for choosing compassion over duty
He will demonstrate spiritual advancement by avoiding killing
questions.feedback: Correct: Krishna warns that refusing this dharmic duty will result in papa (sin) and akirtim (loss of reputation)-not spiritual credit but moral failure. Abandoning prescribed duty isn't transcendence but transgression, regardless of how compassionate the rationalization sounds. This establishes that duty-neglect carries karmic consequences even when motivated by apparently noble sentiment.

questions.prompt: In the purport to BG 2.13, why does Srila Prabhupada say the Mayavadi theory of oneness cannot be entertained?
choices: Because individuality is only a temporary illusion during material existence
Because cutting the Supreme into fragmental souls would make Him changeable
Because oneness philosophy contradicts the need for spiritual teachers
Because the soul's eternal nature prevents any philosophical speculation
questions.feedback: Correct: Srila Prabhupada refutes the Mayavada 'cutting' theory-if souls were cut from the Supreme, He would become changeable, contradicting His immutability. Fragmental portions (vibhinnamshas) exist eternally as individuals-not produced by division but constitutionally distinct. Acintya-bhedabheda (inconceivable oneness-difference) resolves what emanation cannot: simultaneous relationship and distinction without compromising either party's nature.

questions.prompt: In BG 2.38, how does Krishna instruct Arjuna to regard happiness/distress, gain/loss, victory/defeat?
choices: Strive intensely for victory while avoiding defeat at all costs
Treat them as equal and fight, incurring no sin
Abandon fighting to avoid attachment to outcomes
Focus only on happiness and victory as proper motivation
questions.feedback: Correct: Krishna orders Arjuna to treat happiness/distress, gain/loss, victory/defeat as equal and then fight. This is active equanimity: engage in duty without bondage to outcomes. Such equipoise is the basis for sinless action.

questions.prompt: How does Prabhupada's teaching that the body is like clothes (BG 2.22) integrate with Krishna's instruction to fight without attachment to results (BG 2.38, 2.47)?
choices: Soul and bodily action operate in completely separate realms with no connection
Soul-body distinction enables duty performance without existential investment in outcomes
Understanding the soul's nature means one should avoid all material responsibilities
True detachment requires mechanically suppressing all natural emotions during action
questions.feedback: Correct: If the body is like clothing, bodily outcomes do not touch the real self. That insight supports fighting and working without attachment to results (2.38, 2.47). Knowledge turns action into duty and offering rather than egoic grasping.
